QuoteText: You are a slave (in a sense) to the government if they can tell you that you're not allowed to. They will have taken away a person's ability to give birth by their own choice. That is a pretty significant freedom to have, imo. Certainly there are other factors involved, but what I have said here is also true.
ResponseText: So telling you that you cannot steal and kill other people makes you a slave to the government! As for taking away the ability to give birth by thier own choice. It's not exactly that is it?

QuoteText: You are a slave to a fetus( bearing in mind this fetus is your potential son or daughter) if your not allowed to kill it?
ResponseText: You are a slave if you want to choose to terminate your pregnancy and the law prohibits it.

ResponseText: Sinjin. you seem to think that all prolifers are christian nut jobs! I have never claimed that a fetus should have right to life because it has a soul! I also agree that there are cases where a fetus should be aborted! QuoteText: To clarify: human beings have always possessed the inherent right not to be slaves. However, many governments have not recognized and protected this inherent right. This means that governments were not/are not fulfilling their purpose, rather than that human beings do not inherently posses the right.
ResponseText: Then why are you and other profetallifers demanding that pregnant women be made slaves to their fetuses?

QuoteText: Then why are you and other profetallifers demanding that pregnant women be made slaves to their fetuses?
ResponseText: Slavery has a meaning. Prohibiting a person from ending the life of another person does not fall within that meaning.

QuoteText: So telling you that you cannot steal and kill other people makes you a slave to the government! As for taking away the ability to give birth by thier own choice. It's not exactly that is it?
ResponseText: I think the link to slavery was more to do with controlling your body, not necessarily with just limiting freedom (or, at least, that wasn't the extent). Yes, laws prohibiting stealing limits the liberty of one person while protecting the liberty of another. In the end it is a wash. Slavery is so abhorrent not only just because of the loss of freedom, but the dominion over another person in pervasive and complete ways. Basic decisions such as: who I have babies with, do I have a baby now, do I give blood, am I an organ donor, do I eat now or later, what do I eat, when do I sleep and other decisions that seem more fundamentally personal are decided by an outside agency. This strips more than freedom away, it strips dignity and, in some sense, humanity away. This is where the comparison comes from. Perhaps it is wrong to draw a similarity between the complexity that was slavery to this more simple issue, but I think that the horror that many women view the necessarily draconian measures that would have to be put in place to effectively administer a complete moratorium on abortion to be similar in many important respects to slavery. I think it is. Currently there are many safe and effective measures to terminate pregnancy. These would have to be actively denied to pregnant woman who do not wish to be pregnant, effectively making it a requirement that pregnant women must continue their pregnancies by law. If those methods had never been available that might be a different thing.

QuoteText: Not about being a being, bur rather whether as a being I have any inherent dignity and value that commands respect and protection. That is wholly metaphysical. Our unalienable rights today are the same as they have always been. The fact that they may not have been recognized or protected by the government does not mean they didn't exist; it just means that the government was not (and is not) fulfilling its ideal purpose. To clarify: human beings have always possessed the inherent right not to be slaves. However, many governments have not recognized and protected this inherent right. This means that governments were not/are not fulfilling their purpose, rather than that human beings do not inherently posses the right. Yes.
ResponseText: Firstly let me say I have always been impressed with the consistency and continuity of your positions as well as the style with which you defend them. I unfortunately cannot accept the inherency argument or that anything is thereby "commanded". That those rights have not been recognized or protected so often throughout history suggests to me that our rights are plenty "alienable". A gov't that affirms them and protects them is noteworthy but that does not confirm the inherency of those rights. The governments "purpose" hasn't always been to protect the rights of every person living under its control. See, I do know you.
